_exec_summary.SummaryText: on programs and participation in industry safety initiatives help keep our focus on what it takes to "Do It Right." Through our ongoing commitment to make our facility as safe as possible for employees, contractors, the community, and the environment, we are always continuously improving our systems and practices.

Risk Management Program (RMP) Executive Summary
CF Industries Sales, LLC, Velva Terminal

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:
Operating in a safe and responsible manner is a core value and an integral part of CF Industries. Our safety strategy revolves around our "Do It Right" value and permeates our business in three key ways:
¿	Robust systems that provide a clear, repeatable direction toward excellence.
¿	Superior performance that aligns effective and efficient EHS activities with operations.
¿	Engaged culture that empowers consistent behaviors that drive toward excellence.
CF Industries works closely with emergency responders and other local officials to develop detailed emergency response plans that extend beyond our physical operating locations.

Velva Terminal and the regulated substances handled:
Velva Terminal stores and distributes anhydrous ammonia. The regulated substances, as defined by 40 CFR Part 68, which are present at the facility in more than the threshold quantity are anhydrous ammonia.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:
The Velva Terminal has taken all the necessary steps to comply with all of the accidental release and chemical-specific prevention requirements as set forth in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 40 CFR Part 68. This facility is also subject to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard 29 CFR 1910.119. The following summarizes the elements of the release and chemical-specific prevention that are in place at our facility:
¿	Process safety information that is accurate and up to date;
¿	Well-trained operating, maintenance, and contract personnel;
¿	Written operating procedures;
¿	Mechanical integrity procedures for process equipment inspections and quality control;
¿	Management of change and pre-startup safety review procedures;
¿	Periodic, detailed Process Hazard A
